resources.string: This app will intercept incoming text messages and apply the rules you specify. The purpose is to allow you to choose how you receive alerts from specific people or organizations.

When this rule is executed would you like the screen to turn on automatically?

Choose how you would like to filter telephone numbers on incoming text messages?

Enter the digits of the telephone number you are trying to filter based on the rule type selected above.\nNOTE: All phone numbers passed to this application start with \'+\' followed by the country code. If Using \'start with\' you must account for this in your number fragment.

Filter by phone number. Choose from handful of different methods.

This rule applies to phone numbers that contain the entered value.\n\nNOTE: If you know the majority of the number is stable, this is a good one to use to ensure all message from a particular exchange or text message center are captured.
This rule applies to phone numbers that end with the entered value.\n\nNOTE: This is good if you know the entire number but aren\'t familiar with the correct format.
This rule applies to phone numbers that start with the entered value.\n\nNOTE: Most phone numbers start with a \'+\' (plus sign). If you are unsure how to enter this, use \'End With\' instead.

This rule applies to phone numbers that match the entered value exactly.\n\nNOTE: This is good if you know the entire number and are familiar with the correct format that is used when the text message is received. It is a good idea to test this one before relying on it.

This rule applies to phone numbers of the length entered.\n\nNOTE: This is good to use if you wish to capture all numbers of a certain type. Cell phones in the US are always 11 (including the \'+\') in front.

This rule applies to phone numbers that are within the range of numbers entered.\n\nNOTE: This will strip off the \'+\' in front and look for numbers between the 2 entered. Remember to enter the country code.
Play the notification until you dismiss it. This will not read the message aloud.

Ring Once and Read Aloud Once
Play the notification once and read aloud once.
Ring Once then Read Aloud Continuously

Ring Once then Read Aloud Twice, Repeat

Do not play a notification sound, just read the message aloud once.
Do not play a notification sound, just read the message aloud until you dismiss the notification.
The phone will vibrate for 3 seconds.
The phone will vibrate for 3 seconds, then not vibrate for 3 seconds, then repeat.
The times selected are equal. They must span some amount of time.
You must select at least one (1) day for this schedule to be active.
You must add at least one filter.
The phone number filter field cannot be blank. Please enter a number based on the selected rule.

When using the \'Starts With\' rule type, the number filtered needs to start with a \'+\' because phone numbers are received in a normalized format. You can use the contact picker to the right of the input and then remove characters that fit your rule.
The entered value should be a number that is the length of a telephone number. We are expecting it be between 1 and 20.
The value entered is greater than 20. It is unlikely a phone number will have more than 20 characters. Please correct the input.
The lower telephone number must be in the first entry box. Please swap them.

We found some funky characters in one of your range inputs. Please make sure you have only \'+\' and numbers. If you have anything else and you believe it should be valid, please email me: webmaster@3dx2.com.

Thank you for using SMS Alert! This application is designed to intercept text messages that are important to you and alert you over their arrival. The idea came from a volunteer firefighter who wanted to ensure he was always aware messages with high priority.
Please email comments, questions, and enhancement requests to webmaster@3dx2.com

The way this is achieved is by creating rules that will match specific telephone numbers or subsets of telephone numbers. Most times emergency messages come from a central office that owns a group of sms from addresses.
Each rule defines how a message is matched and definitions on how it should be brought to your attention.

To create your first rule, click the \'Add Rule\' button on the main page and follow the on screen instructions. These are very important and following them properly should allow you to intercept messages you care about.
Rules can be deleted by editing them and clicking the \'Delete\' button on the bottom of the screen.
Rules can be globally disabled by unchecking the appropriate box on the main screen. Specific rule enabled settings are retained when you choose to turn the message interception back on.
You are running version %1$s of SMS Alert. This is created by Joshua Ross.
